Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Raman spectra for Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C2 (left) along with enlargement to peaks 127 cm−1 and 719 cm−1. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 FTIR spectra of Ti3C2 (blue line) and ex-Ti3C2 (red line) (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 DR-UV–vis spectra of Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C2. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 X-ray diffraction patterns for Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C2. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms for Ti3C2 and ex- Ti3C2. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 The influence of temperature on the conversion of α-pinene and on the selectivity of the reaction products over Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C2 (catalyst content 5 wt% (in relation to α-pinene), and reaction time 6 h). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 The influence of the Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C2 catalyst content on the conversion of α-pinene and on the selectivity of products (temperature 160 °C, reaction time 6 h). Graphical abstract This work demonstrates a catalytic activity of MXene materials in the isomerization of α-pinene. The temperature influence, catalyst content and reaction time on α-pinene conversion have been revealed. Furthermore, the selectivity of transformation to appropriate products have been investigated. The multilayered and exfoliated Ti3C2Tx have been examined. Both studied MXene materials were active in α-pinene isomerization. However, the exfoliated Ti3C2Tx increased the activity significantly. As a result, an outstanding 100 mol% conversion of α-pinene in 7 h was achieved. It was observed that at optimal operating conditions and catalyst content the selectivity resulted in ∼ 60 mol% toward camphene formation. Additionally, the kinetics of the process has been described. Here, the analysis indicates that the kinetics of α-pinene isomerization over MXene samples was described by first-order kinetics. To the best of our knowledge, it is the highest reported selectivity and conversion reported in the current state of the art. Keywords Ti3C2Tx MXene materials α-pinene isomerization Camphene Kinetics 1 Introduction After the discovery of graphene, very intensive works on the recognition of other two-dimensional materials have begun [1–4]. They have been classified into few groups, such as transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), nitrides (e.g. boron nitride), layered double hydroxides (LDH), early transition metal carbides and/or nitrides (MXenes), transition metal oxides and so on [5–8]. From all of these, MXenes are a new class of 2D materials first reported in 2011 by Naguib, Barsoum, and Gogotsi [9]. Since that time, MXenes have been investigated in various fields. Unlike other layered 2D materials like graphene or phosphorene, which have 3D bulk precursors, MXenes do not have a direct 3D natural precursor. The general formula of MXene is Mn + 1XnTx, where M is the early transition metal, X is carbon and/or nitrogen atoms, n = 1,2,3 and Tx stands for the surface functional groups (OH, O, F) [10]. MXenes are obtained by removing A element (e.g. Al or Si) from MAX phase (Mn+1AXn) by etching in acid solutions, e.g. hydrofluoric acid, NH4HF2 or LiF−HCl [11,12]. MAX phase group of materials has been known for a few decades and can be also called as “metallic ceramics” [13]. The general formula of MAX phase is Mn + 1AXn, where A is mainly 13 or 14 groups element [14]. Over 70 compounds are members of this group and they have been especially applied for high-temperature and extreme environments applications [15]. In MXene family, the number of their members is much higher e.g. by the possibility to induce different surface groups such as O, F or OH on MXene surface during the removal of A element [16,17]. Also, binary metal systems (e.g., Mo2TiC2, Mo2Ti2C3) can be formed what additionally increases the number of MXene members. For those compounds, the general formula is (MxMy)XnTx where x + y=n + 1 [14]. They are well known thermodynamically stable compounds described in the literature [18]. Among all of MXene materials, Ti3C2Tx is the most widely studied. It has been tested in various fields of application. For example, due to positive dielectric loss ability, it can be used as microwave absorbing materials [19]. Outstanding electrical conductivity and high specific surface area have led to numerous applications in the field of electrochemistry such as Li-ion batteries [20], supercapacitors [21,22], or sensors [23]. MXenes are also potential candidates for use as a catalyst in hydrogen evolution reaction and water splitting [24]. They also adsorb heavy metal ions and organic contaminants from water exhibiting very good catalytic and photocatalytic properties [24,25]. However, so far MXene materials have not been tested as catalysts in the processes of the isomerization or oxidation of olefinic compounds, e.g. α-pinene. α-Pinene is widely used as a fragrance in cosmetics and household industry. Moreover, it is applied in medicine as a drug and as a raw material in the synthesis of different medicinal products [26]. It is also used as a precursor of camphene for synthetic camphor production on an industrial scale [27]. Camphene is used as the valuable intermediate in organic synthesis, among others for the production of toxaphene (insecticide) [28], synthetic camphor (plasticizer in explosives, production of insect repellents, food additive, and in medicine as a warming substance and a drug used in the treatment of failure hearts) [27] and terpenecyclohexanols (an alternative to sandalwood oil used in perfumery) [29]. In addition, camphene is applied as a fragrance and flavoring substance [30]. This compound is also used in the production of cleaning agents that are designed to mask unpleasant odors (mainly as toilet fragrances). Interestingly, it was also applied in medicine, for example in a mixture with pinene and cineol it is used for renal and hepatobiliary disorders [31]. Moreover, studies also indicate that it has anticancer properties [32]. In the industrial method of α-pinene isomerization, titanium dioxide (TiO2) is used as a catalyst. First, titanium dioxide is pre-treated with acid to form titanic acid layer on the catalyst surface. The isomerization reaction is carried out under normal pressure and at the temperatures above 155 °C for 24 h. The main products are camphene, limonene and tricyclene. These compounds are obtained with a total yield of 85 % [33,34]. However, due to the long reaction time and gradual deactivation, the new candidates catalyzing this process are currently explored. New catalysts should exhibit higher activity and higher selectivity of transformation to the most desirable product - camphene. The current state of the art delivers interesting reports on such catalysts as mesoporous materials – including mesoporous titanium silicate Ti-SBA-15 and Ti-MCM-41 [35–38], zirconia [39,40], natural zeolites [41,42] and alumina [43]. The highest selectivity of transformation to camphene was obtained for dealuminated ferrite-type zeolite [41] and it reached 50 % at the 100 % conversion of α-pinene (temperature 90 °C, reaction time 3 h). However, there is still plenty of room in this research field to explore the catalysts with higher selectivity. The aim of this work was to reveal the catalytic performance of Ti3C2 MXene in the process of the isomerization of α-pinene. Similarly, to the catalysts with a zeolite-like structure, Ti3C2 MXene contains an active center with titanium incorporated in its structure. Therefore, it is believed that Ti3C2 MXene can efficiently catalyze the α-pinene isomerization process. The optimal operation conditions towards the highest selectivity of camphene and conversion of α-pinene, while significantly reducing the selectivity of the transformation to other products will be here explored. Additionally, the kinetics model of the process will be proposed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of Ti3AlC2 MAX phase The preparation of Ti3AlC2 MAX phase is typically based on the processes of self-propagating high-temperature syntheses (SHS) [44]. However, here it was successfully obtained using the powder metallurgy technique and Spark Plasma Sintering (SPS) method. The following substrates are used: titanium powder (GoodFellow, Great Britain), aluminum powder (Benda-Lutz Skawina, Poland) and synthetic graphite powder (Sigma Aldrich, USA). Firstly, the above-mentioned powders are wet blended in isopropyl alcohol with a molar ratio Ti:Al:C = 3:1.1:1.8 using ball type mill. After drying, the obtained powders mixture is sieved (# = 300 μm). The special design of graphite die allows to conduct the reactive synthesis process with the use of pressure less SPS technique [45]. The parameters of the synthesis process presented in this work are as follows: temperature of 1300 °C, heating rate of 250 °C/min, vacuum atmosphere. After cooling of the final product, the obtained MAX phase was grinded using an automatic mortar grinder (Retsch KM100) and then sieved (# = 300 μm). Thus obtained Ti3AlC2 powder was subjected to the process of HF-etching. 2.2 Preparation of multilayered Ti3C2Tx MXene The process of acidic etching aims to remove aluminum (Al) from the sandwiched Ti3C2-Al-Ti3C2-Al-Ti3C2 structure and obtain Ti3C2 layers interleaved by slit-shaped pores which appear in cavity formed after Al removed. The process of etching was carried out using a hydrofluoric acid (HF) protocol. The MAX phase powder (10 g) was carefully immersed in 48 % HF water solution (Sigma-Aldrich) which was continuously stirred with 250 rpm. The involved chemical reactions result in the generation of gaseous hydrogen (H2). To enable mild reaction process and effective H2 removal, the ratio of MAX phase to HF solution was fixed at 1 g: 10 cm3, respectively. The etching process was carried out for 24 h at room temperature with continuous stirring and fume hood protection. The resulting suspension was then allowed to sediment. The obtained supernatant was discarded and the Ti3C2 MXene was washed four times with deionized water and technical grade ethanol. The such prepared multilayered Ti3C2Tx was dried overnight at room temperature and stored in 5 °C for further use and testing. The sample was further designated as Ti3C2. 2.3 Preparation of exfoliated 2D Ti3C2Tx MXene 100 mg of Ti3C2 MXene powder was mixed with 10 ml of deionized H2O containing 100 mg of tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMAOH) in a 20-mL glass vial, and the mixture was stirred for 24 h at room temperature. The basic mixture (∼ pH 10) was mildly sonicated for 6 h and washed repeatedly via centrifugation (3500 rpm, 5 min per cycle) using 50 ml tube to bring the pH to ∼7. The stable MXene colloidal solutions were collected after 1 h of centrifugation at 3500 rpm, and the sediment was collected via vacuum-assisted filtration. The sample was then redispersed in deionized water and freeze-dried for 24 h to obtain final samples. The as-prepared exfoliated 2D Ti3C2Tx sample was designated as ex-Ti3C2. 2.4 Characterization The morphology of the samples was studied by scanning electron microscopy (TESCAN, VEGA 3, acquired in the 30 kV acceleration voltage) and transmission electron microscope (Tecnai F20-based at 200 kV accelerating voltage). To determine the thickness and vertical size of samples atomic force microscope was introduced (Tecnai F20-based at 200 kV accelerating voltage). Raman spectroscopy was conducted using inVia Raman Microscope (RENISHAW IN VIA Raman Microscope Spectrometer) with an excitation wavelength of 785 nm. Fourier transform infrared reflection (FTIR) spectra were carried out on Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer. The optical absorption spectra of the materials were tested in a Jasco UV–vis spectrophotometer (JASCO V-770) in the diffuse reflectance mode. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained by Empyrean Philips diffractometer using CuK α radiation. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area was measured by nitrogen sorption in the temperature of liquid nitrogen using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460. The acid sites concentration (Ns) of Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C2 was measured using the method described by Vilcocq et al. [46]. Briefly, 20 mg of the appropriate sample was added to 10 cm3 of 0.01 M NaOH solution and mixed at room temperature for 4 h. Next, the sample was filtered off and the pH of the filtrate was determined by the titration with 0.01 M HCl in the presence of phenolphthalein as an indicator. The acid sites concentration was calculated from the formula 1: N s = O H − 0 − O H − 4 h * V m where [OH−] is the hydroxide molar concentration determined by the titration (mol/dm3), V is the volume of NaOH solution added to the studied material (ml) and m is the mass of Ti3C2 or ex-Ti3C2 (mg). 2.5 Isomerization of α-pinene The activity of Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C2 materials in the isomerization of α-pinene was carried out in a 25-cm3 glass reactor equipped with a reflux condenser and magnetic stirrer with heating. 1 g of α-pinene (98 %, Aldrich) and the appropriate amount of the catalyst were introduced into the reactor, which was then placed in an oil bath. The mixing speed was constant and amounted to 400 rpm. The effect of the following parameters was examined: temperature (in the range of 140−170 °C), catalyst content (in the range of 1−10 wt.%), and reaction time (from 1 to 24 h). For quantitative and qualitative analyses, the post-reaction mixtures were centrifuged and dissolved in acetone in a weight ratio of 1:3. The qualitative analyses were performed by GC–MS method using a ThermoQuest apparatus equipped with a Voyager detector and a DB-5 column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.5 μm). The parameters of analyses were as follows: helium flow of 1 mL/min, the temperature of the sample chamber of 200 °C, the temperature of a detector of 250 °C, the temperature of the furnace was set isothermally for 2.5 min to the temperature of 50 °C, then increased with the speed of 10 °C/min to the temperature of 300 °C. The quantitative analyses were performed with a Thermo Electron FOCUS chromatograph equipped with an FID detector and a ZB-1701 column (30 m × 0.53 mm × 1 μm). The parameters of the analyses were set for helium flow of 1 mL/min, the sample chamber temperature of 220 °C, detector temperature of 250 °C, the temperature of the furnace was reached isothermally for 2 min to the temperature of 50 °C followed by increase with the speed of 5 °C/min to 100 °C, finally, with the speed of 10 °C/min the temperature reached 200 °C. To determine the composition of the post-reaction mixtures an internal normalization method was used. The mass balance allowed to calculate the conversion of α-pinene and the product selectivity (camphene, limonene, α-terpinene, γ-terpinene, terpinolene, tricyclene and p-cymene). Additionally, the summed selectivity of other products of the isomerization process was calculated (small amounts of fenchene, polymer compounds and oxidation products). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C2 SEM images of the multilayered and exfoliated Ti3C2 samples are presented in Fig. 1 . The reference multilayered Ti3C2 (Fig. 1a, b) exhibits a typical lamellar structure with clear spacing between the nanosheets. That accordion-like structure has disappeared after exfoliation (Fig. 1c, d). In the resulting 2D structure (ex-Ti3C2) decrease in the number of layers is seen and the distance between individual layers has been expanded. Also, the surface of ex-Ti3C2 is more wrinkled and irregular. Based on SEM it was noticed that the thickness of layers in ex-Ti3C2 has significantly decreased in comparison to the multilayered Ti3C2. It was proved by the AFM analysis (Fig. 2 a, b). The thickness of ex-Ti3C2 flakes is in the range from 30 to 50 nm. This corresponds to ∼ 30–50 layers in ex-Ti3C2, where the monolayer of Ti3C2 is 1 nm thick [47]. The change in the number of Ti3C2 layers after exfoliation is significant in respect to the pristine Ti3C2. According to the SEM image (Fig. 1a and b), the thickness of Ti3C2 and the distance between individual Ti3C2 layers are ∼ 5−10 μm and ∼ 0.3−0.4 μm, respectively. Fig. 3 shows the Raman spectra of Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C2. Five sharp peaks at ∼ 127, 206, 364, 624 and 719 cm−1 were observed for the multilayered Ti3C2. They are characteristic of Ti3C2 MXene [9,48–50]. Additionally, peaks at ∼ 364, 624 and 719 cm−1 can be assigned to Ti-C vibrations [48]. Raman spectrum of ex-Ti3C2 exhibits shifted peaks comparing to Ti3C2. For example, peaks at 127 and 719 cm−1 (Ti3C2) were shifted to 124 and 739 cm−1 (ex-Ti3C2), respectively. This phenomenon can be attributed to the reduction in the number of layers [51]. FTIR spectra of Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C2 are shown in Fig. 4 . According to the literature data [52], the peaks at 3434 and 1630 cm−1 confirm the existence of OH groups in both samples. Those bands can be assigned to the absorbed external water and strongly hydrogen-bonded OH groups or extremely strong coordinated H2O. Moreover, the presence of OH groups can be also confirmed by the peak at ∼ 1400 cm−1. In addition, this absorption band can be attributed to CO groups in the form of the carboxyl group (COOH) [53]. The peaks observed at 1481 cm−1 (Ti3C2) and 1464 cm−1 (ex-Ti3C2) correspond to the CH bonds [52]. Whereas, three bands (2852, 2916 and 2953 cm−1) in the 2852−2953 cm−1 region are assigned to aliphatic CH stretching vibrations and CH2 groups [52,53]. The band at 950 cm−1, is present only in the FTIR spectrum of ex-Ti3C2, and is attributed to TiO stretching vibrations of bridging hydroxyls group [54]. Moreover, the bands at 643 and 574 cm−1, observed for ex-Ti3C2, correspond to TiO bond [53] or TiOTi stretching vibration [55]. In Ti3C2 spectrum the peak at ∼ 744 cm−1, assigned to CO group (stretching vibration), is observed [56]. The peak at 617 cm−1, present only in Ti3C2, is probably attributed to the deformation vibration of the TiO bond [52]. Fig. 5 depicts the UV–vis diffuse reflectance (DR) spectra of Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C2. For both samples, clear two peaks at 240 and 305 nm are observed. The band centered at 230 nm is assigned to tetrahedrally coordinated Ti species, whereas, the band at ∼ 305 nm probably corresponds to five- and six-coordinated Ti species [57]. The diffraction patterns of Ti3C2 before and after exfoliation are presented in Fig. 6 . Both curves exhibit signals characteristic for Ti3C2 [49,58,59]. After exfoliation the intensity and shape of the peaks are different. The fact that the thickness of the peaks increased after the exfoliation process suggests that the crystallinity has decreased. This proves that the exfoliation process has been carried out successfully without destroying the composition of the material. In Fig. 7 , the typical IV isotherm with H3 hysteresis loops is observed, which is typical of mesoporous materials. The isotherm shape confirms the slit-shaped porous structure for both samples [60]. The position of the P/P0 inflection points is associated with the range of mesopore sizes, and the slope degree indicates the uniformity of mesopore size. For Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C2 their specific surface areas are 6.6 and 87.5 m2/g, respectively. This indicates that the exfoliation process caused a huge increase in the specific surface area. The titration of the acid sites performed for the studied samples allowed to obtain the following results: 2.17 mmolH + gcat −1 and 2.92 mmolH + gcat −1 for Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C3, respectively. These results are in line with the catalytic activity tests which showed a considerable increase in the catalytic activity of ex-Ti3C3 in respect to multilayered Ti3C2 (detailed results are presented below). 3.2 Studies on the activity of the Ti3C2 MXene materials The activity of the obtained samples (Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C2) was studied in the reaction of α-pinene isomerization. Firstly, the effect of temperature (140−170 °C) on the activity of Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C2 (Fig. 8 ) was examined. The other reaction parameters such as reaction time (6 h) and catalyst content (5 wt.% - in relation to α-pinene) were selected based on our previous studies [35,36]. Fig. 8 exhibited that with an increase in the temperature from 140 to 170 °C, the conversion of α-pinene increased to a maximum possible value (100 mol% at 170 °C) for both studied samples. However, at lower temperatures (150 °C and 160 °C), ex-Ti3C2 shows much higher activity than unmodified Ti3C2. For example, the values of the conversion of α-pinene are 60.2 mol% (ex-Ti3C2) and 47.8 mol% (Ti3C2) at 160 °C. Moreover, at this temperature, the highest selectivity of camphene is obtained (59.4 mol% for Ti3C2 and 59.3 mol% for ex-Ti3C2). Other by-products formed with high selectivity at 160 °C are limonene (∼ 21−23 mol%) and tricyclene (∼ 8 mol%) for both studied catalysts. Next, the influence of catalyst content (Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C2) ranged from 1 to10 wt% (in relation to α-pinene) on the process of α-pinene isomerization at 160 °C (the most beneficial temperature) was revealed (Fig. 9 ). The 10 wt% catalyst content is the highest due to difficulties in the mixing of the reaction mixture. The conversion of α-pinene increased from 4.9 to 76.7 mol% (catalyst content - 10 wt%) with an increase in Ti3C2 content. In contrast, in ex-Ti3C2 74.7 mol% of conversion was obtained for the catalyst content of 7.5 wt%. Moreover, the product selectivity is similar for both samples. The enhanced activity of ex-Ti3C2 can be explained by: (1) higher specific surface of ex-Ti3C2 (87.5 m2/g) than Ti3C2 (6.6 m2/g), (2) higher amount of acid sites of ex-Ti3C2 (2.92 mmolH+gcat −1) than Ti3C2 (2.17 mmolH+gcat −1) and (3) the problem of mass exchange in the reaction mixture at high Ti3C2 contents. Moreover, the spacing between the nanosheets in MXenes can affect the course of α-pinene isomerization and the type of received products. Too small distance between the nanosheets can limit access of α-pinene molecules to active sites and inhibit the reaction. Therefore, the products that will easily fit into this space may be favored. So, the higher activity of ex-Ti3C2 may also result from the expanded distance between the individual layers. This problem requires further, detailed research, which will be conducted in future studies. The phenomenon of metal leaching from the structure of catalysts on their activity is also often described in the literature [63]. Therefore, future research on the mechanism of isomerization and the loss of activity of our catalyst should be also further explored. In the reaction mechanism describing the course of α-pinene isomerization [35] the key stage is the attachment of proton to the α-pinene molecule and formation of pinanyl cation. The IR and UV–vis spectra (see Fig. 4 and 5) of Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C2 indicate the presence of −OH groups bonded via Ti atoms, as well as TiO and TiO-Ti groups, which also can be easily transformed into TiOH groups. Their abundance is crucial as they are a source of the protons that initiate the isomerization process. After detachment of the proton, they will be transformed into TiO and TiOTi groups. Finally, the effect of the reaction time (1−24 h) on the α-pinene isomerization was studied. Here, a larger amount of the reaction mixture was used (5 g of α-pinene was mixed with 7.5 wt.% of catalyst). The obtained results are presented in Fig. 10 . They indicate that for ex-Ti3C2 the conversion of α-pinene is ∼ 91 mol% after 3 h. In comparison, the conversion of α-pinene is 48 mol% for Ti3C2. The conversion of α-pinene after 4 h is ∼ 95 mol% and 58 mol% for ex-Ti3C2 and Ti3C2, respectively. It is interesting that after the reaction time of 24 h the side reactions (isomerization of camphene, dimerization and polymerization of products) barely occur. The product selectivity is similar for the reaction time in the range of 1–7 h. However, after the reaction time of 24 h only a slight conversion of limonene to α-terpinene, terpinolene and p-cymene is detected. 3.3 Kinetic studies In this work, the kinetic analysis of α-pinene isomerization was performed. It was assumed that the α-pinene isomerization rate can be described by Eq. (2): (2) - d C α - p i n e n e d t = k C α - p i n e n e n where Cα-pinene is α-pinene concentration, t is reaction time, k is reaction rate coefficient and n is kinetic order. The rate Eq. (2) was tested for n = 0, 1, 1.5 and 2. For mathematical modeling, the following equations in their integral forms were used Eqs. (3)–(5): for the zero-order: (3) C α - p i n e n e , 0 - C α - p i n e n e = k t for the first-order: (4) l n C α - p i n e n e , 0 C α - p i n e n e = k t for the orders different from 0 and 1: (5) 1 C α - p i n e n e n - 1 - 1 C α - p i n e n e , 0 n - 1 = n - 1 k t where Cα-pinene,0 is initial α-pinene concentration. The highest regression coefficient (R2) was found for n = 1 (Table 1 ). This indicates that the α-pinene isomerization over Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C2 is the first-order reaction. The reaction rate coefficients for both catalysts were calculated and presented in Table 1. The value of reaction rate coefficients for ex-Ti3C2 is nearly three times higher than for Ti3C2 thus the isomerization of α-pinene over Ti3C2 is much faster than over ex-Ti3C2. The reaction network of the simplified mechanism of α-pinene isomerization is given in Fig. 11 . While the advanced mechanism of α-pinene isomerization was proposed and presented in Table 2 . A correct reaction mechanism is crucial for accurate predictive modeling. The proposed reaction mechanism was described by eight reaction routes (columns numbered from N(1) to N(8)). The chemical equations of elementary and intermediate steps containing reactants and surface species were placed in seventeen rows. It was assumed that the rates leading to camphene and tricyclene (1→2→4→6, 1→2→5→7) as well p-cymene (1→3→8→14→17, 1→3→12→16→17, 1→3→10→15→17) were not interconnected. The p-cymene is formed by irreversible routes from limonene, terpinolene and/or α + γ-terpinene. To understand the meaning of 1, 0 and -1 digits shown in Table 2, a brief explanation must be provided: • unity is synonymous with the occurrence of the sequence of elementary reaction which must run from reactants to products, e. g. 1 (marked by bold and underlined digit at the intersection of 3rd row and 5th column) means that α-pinene leads to terpinolene only when it is supported by an irreversible formation of Z·(α-pinene)2 from Z·(α-pinene); • zero indicates that a reaction equation described in a row is not interconnected with a product placed in a column e.g. 0 (marked by bold and underlined digit at the intersection of 10th row and 1st column) means that this is impossible to lead tricyclene from Z·(α-pinene)2 or (α + γ-terpinene) because both paths are not connected; • unity with minus corresponds to a reaction wherein an intermediate product is consumed to the final product in one step e. g. -1 (marked by bold and underlined digit at the intersection of 13th row and 8th column) means that p-cymene as the final product is formed in one step from terpinolene (intermediate product); Detailed kinetic modeling with the comprehensive derivation and parameter estimation for a system of differential equations was elaborated. However, here we present only some of the results. For the analysis of selectivity dependence, differential Eqs. (6–9) were proposed: (6) − d C t r i c y c l e n e d C α − p i n e n e = f 1 + f 2 C c a m p h e n e C α − p i n e n e − f 3 C t r i c y c l e n e C α − p i n e n e (7) − d C c a m p h e n e d C α − p i n e n e = f 4 − f 2 C c a m p h e n e C α − p i n e n e + f 3 C t r i c y c l e n e C α − p i n e n e (8) − d C lim o n e n e d C α − p i n e n e = f 5 − f 6 C lim o n e n e C α − p i n e n e (9) − d C p − c y m e n e d C α − p i n e n e = f 7 + f 8 C lim o n e n e C α − p i n e n e + f 9 C α + γ − t e r p i n e n e C α − p i n e n e + f 10 C t e r p i n o l e n e C α − p i n e n e The values of the dimensionless parameters in equations (6)–(9) were obtained for α-pinene isomerization over ex-Ti3C2 and are given in Table 3 . The kinetic modeling proved that α-pinene isomerization over Ti3C2 and ex-Ti3C2 followed the first-order kinetics. Ünveren et al. [42] and Allahverdiev et al. [61] also reported that the isomerization of α-pinene was the first order reaction over acid treated natural zeolites and clinoptilolite, respectively. Although, Rudakov et al. [62] revealed that α-pinene isomerization over titanium catalyst followed according to the zero-order kinetic model. 4 Conclusions MXene materials, multilayered and exfoliated Ti3C2, were tested as catalysts in the α-pinene isomerization. Here, the influence of different reaction conditions (temperature, catalyst content and reaction time) on the selectivity of appropriate products and conversion of α-pinene was studied. The results revealed that both Ti3C2 materials are active in the process of α-pinene isomerization. However, exfoliated Ti3C2 shows much higher activity in comparison to the multilayered Ti3C2. ex-Ti3C2 showed 100 mol% conversion of α-pinene in 7 h of process. The main reaction products of the studied process are camphene, limonene and tricyclene, which are formed with the total selectivity over 90 mol%. The kinetics modeling was performed using a complex reaction network as well as a chemical equation system. The isomerization of α-pinene over both samples followed the first-order kinetics. The proposed model was well fitted to the experimental data. It was stated that the reaction network consists of 17 elementary reactions. The comparison of the presented results with our results obtained for titanium silicate materials such as Ti-SBA-15 [35] and Ti-MCM-41 [36] revealed that the selectivity of camphene at the 100 mol% conversion of α-pinene is ∼ 2 times higher for Ti3C2 samples (60 mol%) in respect to Ti-SBA-15 (26 mol%) and Ti-MCM-41 (35 mol%). Furthermore, in the case of both studied Ti3C2 materials, undesired dimerization and polymerization reactions leading to a decrease in the selectivity of the most valuable products (camphene, limonene and tricyclene) are not detected. Summarizing, a new class of catalyst in the isomerization of α-pinene is proposed. It is also very important that α-pinene isomerization process does not require (i) the use of a large amount of catalyst, (ii) the presence of solvent and (iii) the use of sophisticated equipment. Therefore, increasing its scale should not be difficult. Further research should be directed towards a modification of MXene materials to increase their activity testing even smaller amounts of the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: This work demonstrates a catalytic activity of MXene materials in the isomerization of α-pinene. The temperature influence, catalyst content and reaction time on α-pinene conversion have been revealed. Furthermore, the selectivity of transformation to appropriate products have been investigated. The multilayered and exfoliated Ti3C2Tx have been examined. Both studied MXene materials were active in α-pinene isomerization. However, the exfoliated Ti3C2Tx increased the activity significantly. As a result, an outstanding 100 mol% conversion of α-pinene in 7 h was achieved. It was observed that at optimal operating conditions and catalyst content the selectivity resulted in ∼ 60 mol% toward camphene formation. Additionally, the kinetics of the process has been described. Here, the analysis indicates that the kinetics of α-pinene isomerization over MXene samples was described by first-order kinetics. To the best of our knowledge, it is the highest reported selectivity and conversion reported in the current state of the art.
coredata.dc:title: High catalytic performance of 2D Ti3C2Tx MXene in α-pinene isomerization to camphene
